channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description:
@ternoveau @436bGliese @wideofthepost @haymarketbooks Exactly.

Javert was indeed a tragic hero.

The system failed _everyone_. Miserably.

(At least we have space weapons and Netflix now, so progress?)

@sp_redelectric @offlineleft @PresidentJose3 @AmtrakConnects Fair. At least those in Europe have options (and @db_bahn has a great website).

In most places in the USA lucky enough to be connected by @Amtrak interstate trains, there is often only one train per day, making connections _very_ difficult (even _if_ the first train is on time).

@sp_redelectric @offlineleft @PresidentJose3 @AmtrakConnects @DB_Bahn @Amtrak Also, some folks appear lucky, e.g.: - Paris - Venice with only one connection (#TGV-#EC). - London - Amsterdam with zero (@Eurostar).

București to Málaga has a ton of connections, I'll give you that!

@sp_redelectric @offlineleft @PresidentJose3 @AmtrakConnects One sometimes has to change trains three times between one side of NYC and another side of NYC.

If train schedules are reasonably aligned and with frequent service, connections can be a nice change to stretch ones legs / make phone calls / etc.

@sp_redelectric @offlineleft @PresidentJose3 @AmtrakConnects A direct flight between DC to NYC require at least three transport segments, too, if one includes the car/Uber/subway to&from airports.

All often paid/ticketed separately.

(… that’s before taking into considering rental car shuttles, inter-terminal shuttle trains/busses, etc.)
@BMunise @offlineleft That makes us look even worse!

@SherlockHemloc2 @wideofthepost Drug crimes are signs of systemic societal dysfunction.

Until we confront that, any ‘war on drugs’ has less chance of sustained success than a land war in Asia.
@propcharles @jcschmieder @wideofthepost Or leave your doors unlocked with a $20 on the seat.

@jcschmieder @wideofthepost The same ‘innocent’ residents that routinely drive by their unhoused cousins and do little or nothing to help?

(help can be provided in many non-financial ways - being active in local politics, befriending folks on the street, etc…)

@436bGliese @wideofthepost @haymarketbooks It’s a terrible tragic tale.

Javert worked so hard, from nothing, and all he ever wanted was respect for doing the right thing.
@daniellamyoung [link]

@pattyheffley @Sallamoon1 @joeyfox85 A damp towel placed over an inexpensive box fan not only cools (slightly) the air but humidifies it as well.

A pan of water left on top of a radiator or inside a sunny winter window helps with humidity, too.

@BlueDebonair @jessejanderson Additional compensation tactic I just remembered:

Before clearing / any mess (desk / office / garage / whiteboard), regardless of what organizational method is to be used,

—> I always try to take one or more detailed photographs.

@BlueDebonair @jessejanderson That way, I can always scroll back through my photo library, zoom in on the relevant photos, and search for something of which I have a spatial recollection.

I don’t sort the photos or put them in albums. I rarely look back at them, but it’s sure nice to have the option!

@BlueDebonair @jessejanderson Finally, for really big or important jobs, I’ll actually also use a dedicated audio recorder (digital or microcassette, as long as it has voice-activated ‘VOX’) mode. I say the date / place at the very start, then narrate what I’m doing (e.g.“putting holiday wreath into red box”)

@Kelsie_McVeety @the_tweedy A non-preferred name shouldn’t appear _anywhere_ on paperwork or computer screens past reception.

(If it has to appear for some legal/regulatory reason, in should be in a very tiny font away from other names.)

@brydone_jack @AlissaEvenson @TSevert @Fad1878 Perhaps they’re used to rural providers not having good equipment to read disks… also, a cracked film is readable; a cracked CD might not be.

(also, the film is likely to still be readable in 20 years… but will a computer with CD drive be common in 2040?)

@melarune @BlueDebonair @jessejanderson That’s the trap, though! You don’t have to catalogue _all_ of your belongings, just one thing.

Later, do one more thing.

Partial organization is better than none; you’ll be able to find at least those 2 things. :)

@BlueDebonair @jessejanderson What I have heard most often is that any useful storage tend to be

- open / transparent

… or …

- closed and cataloged

@BlueDebonair @jessejanderson Personally, I use numbered ‘Banker’s Boxes’ stacked floor to ceiling inside of a large closet, and a clipboard (with pre-lined paper) that lives on a wall hook just outside the closet door.

One could instead use any nice-looking box/drawer/bin/jar.

@BlueDebonair @jessejanderson A. Want to store something?

1. Write name of thing on clipboard, 2. open door, 3. find _any_ box with free space and insert item 4. write box number on clipboard.

@BlueDebonair @jessejanderson B. Want to find something?

1. Flip through pages on clipboard to find where you wrote down the thing. 2. Cross-off item from list and 3. grab item from that numbered box.

@BlueDebonair @jessejanderson The clipboard (and attached pen/pencil) is _never_ allowed to leave its home!

I’ve taped a note to the back saying “If found, smack me upside the head with this, then insist I return it to its proper home.”

(Added benefit: other people can help store/find items without me.)

@BlueDebonair @jessejanderson Barcodes.

… and a database.

(think less ‘library’ and more ‘Amazon fulfillment center’)
@TeeDee32390904 @LadiRadi Apparently there exist machinations that cause many defendants to ‘waive’ that right…
